participants.participant: Chng Sok Hui, Chief Financial Officer

plist.p: Good afternoon friends from the media. I believe this is a press conference that many of you have been waiting for. Yeah, we are very pleased to have Piyush with us. This is his first press conference, since he joined DBS and so what we'll do with regard to the rundown for today's media conference, Piyush will kick-off with basically sharing with us some of his first impression since he has joined DBS.

Today is his 89th day with the bank, yes, right he joined us on November the 9th, after that we'll hand over the floor over to Sok Hui, who will go through the FY, our Full Year 2009 financials and then in addition to talking about his first impression, Piyush also gives you sort of a high level overview of our results for this year.

After Sok Hui finishes, Piyush will come back and then share with us, basically his thoughts and his views on the bank's strategic priorities going forward. So on that note without further ado, I'll pass the floor to Piyush. Thanks.

I'm not supposed to talk about first impressions. Okay listen. Hi, thanks for being here and I guess I can talk about first impressions because I just spent a couple of hours with our employees and staff during our town hall, and so I did talk to everybody there about first impressions.

And I guess, and I made a joke there, which is true, I didn't realize it was day 89. But I'm not counting, Karen is, so that must mean something. You know, I looked around, let me break it into two parts. It's quite clear as you go through the DBS thing that there is some really great strengths DBS has. And some of these I knew when I came in. Some of these really were things that struck me over the last two or three months that I've been around. Some are pretty obvious.

So, clearly the first thing that stands out, as I go round this whole thing of financial strength. This is not new stuff for you guys but it is really important. We are one of the only, I think 23 was the last count somebody told me, but let's say one of the top, it was a 25 AA or AA minus/plus rated banks in the world. That's actually quite a big deal. And the fact as I go around and review our businesses in other countries, that strength, the inherent strength of DBS, which is sort of epitomizes and embodies the strength of Singapore, actually means a lot.

So through the crisis, it was quite clear that irrespective of issues and there was a clear flight to quality, and whether it's in the consumer space or in the institutional space, people, when they look at a diversified banking portfolio or banking providers, we stand out and people are willing to look at us, just because it's a strong bank. And again, from outside, I sort of knew this but having come into the Bank and being around and met our clients and our people, it's pretty stark, how relevant that is.

The other thing which struck me is something again I hadn't expected positively, is the brand resonance that the DBS brand has. And Singapore it's a obvious thing, right? Everybody knows DBS and we're not the competitor at the other end of DBS in terms of brand recognition, there is no question who is the market leader. But the interesting thing, as you go around the region, the DBS brand has relevance and resonance in strange places. Indonesia, it's really well known, it's a well-known brand people recognize it and sort of see it as Singapore.

But in Hong Kong and Taiwan, I was quite interested and surprised as we went on our service shows, we are seen as a progressive bank and that's actually a good place to be, to be a progressive bank and a progressive brand. So another second big positive to me, it's actually a good brand, which has relevance in countries outside Singapore alone. Clearly, in India and China, we are small and, therefore, brand recognition is more of a challenge. But certainly in the other countries I mentioned it was a relative positive.

I think the third thing, which I looked around, I was joking to the people earlier. When I took the job, one of my concerns at the back of my head obviously was I'd spent 28 years with a multinational American bank and I'm moving to a bank, which is Singaporean and on top of that, government linked. So the issue of the people and the cultural challenge is obviously something, which I was worried about. And frankly if I had to say, what's really been the most positive part of the thing of my experience so far, it has been exactly that I just find that the people quality is at least as good, the people quality I've been used to in my previous place.

We've got good people. We've got, and frankly in some places in the newer countries, because we are a young bank, we've got actually very energetic and young people. And that's a good thing. I feel good about it. One of the things that again, there's is no secret in the past in its history, DBS' leadership was questioned for its solidarity or collectivity and frankly in the last couple of years, from everything I can see under Boon Hwee's leadership and maybe riches, it has come a long, long way. We've got a really good unified collective leadership, which is actually top class. So, it's good. Also I was struck by, clearly some business which everybody knows are good franchises that DBS has.

And when you come and look at from the inside, they really stand out. The Singapore consumer footprint is obviously immense. It's unique, principally on the back of the POSB franchise. Now I'll talk about it in a bit. We could have done more with that footprint and frankly we recognized it. But the fact remains that if you have a banking relationship with 90% of the people in this country, that's a fantastic asset. People would pay their left arms to be able to own such an asset. So it's something that we should really be able to work and do stuff off. The part that surprised me. I have always felt from outside and my understanding was that DBS is really a top end corporate bank, right?

So its roots are in the development bank thing, and it's sort of democratic linked and government linked and so on and so forth. I was actually very pleasantly surprised to see how robust and how strongly flourishing our SME and mid-market portfolio book is. It's the fastest growing part of our corporate banking business. And it's now a substantial part of our corporate banking business.

And also as we look at countries outside of Singapore, it is clearly a segment that we have some fairly good positions in. So that was a positive and a surprise. And obviously, the other thing, which was not a surprise but has really reinforced my thinking, we have a world-class treasury and markets business. So we just – it competes on a world-class level with most of the global players and global houses. And frankly, as I looked at it, our understanding and management of market risk is also world class. It is very, very superior, very class. So a lot of strength in the franchise which I saw as I went around. By the way, the other thing I should say is – the one thing which is again obvious but again stands out to you.

We have good geographic platforms, right. So we're one of the few players, we've got a good platform in Greater China. Our acquisition of Bowa Bank in Taiwan was good. We've got a 40-branch presence there. Obviously, Hong Kong has been there for sometime. And our organic growth, our business in China has actually been doing well, has been growing out quite nicely. But also, one of the few, probably the only Asian bank, which really has a footprint there or footprint here and also footprint in India. And it's important. It's a really well – relatively well-balanced geographic footprint.

Now there's issues obviously. The biggest issue, which is a tactical issue, which several of – is that we are really a very deposit-flush bank. So, we're a deposit-surplus bank and therefore we're a lot more susceptible to the vagaries of the interest rate cycle than other banks are. So in low interest rate environments, we hurt more than other banks hurt. And that's an issue, so what that really means as we think of about our future. We've got to figure a way to building a more balanced balance sheet, right.

So that's an issue for us. I referred to it earlier, we've got a fantastic consumer franchise, but if we really think about what we've been able to do in terms of building on or building out that franchise, we have an opportunity. We have work to do. So being able to create a broader and more robust relationship with our consumer base in Singapore, leveraging on POSB. That's an area that there is clearly opportunities to do better than we have.

People have commented and you go round the streets in Singapore, you will see queues in front of the DBS ATMs. I do never see queues in front of the other two you see, and that's because they are very heavily used. And a statistic, which I learned, our usage of ATMs is the highest of any bank anywhere in the world, DBS ATMs, right. It's just very, very heavily used, Now that's a strength, but obviously focusing on being able to improve the consumer experience, being able to put the consumer experience in the heart of what we do, is an opportunity.

So we need to be able to do a better job of that than we've been able to in the past and that's something that's part of what we will build. And frankly from a franchise standpoint, I said that, we have some great business franchises. There are challenges. We have a presence and footprint in India and China, but quite clearly the regulatory environment there is not as friendly to rapid growth as it is in other markets. So we've got to work with that and work around that. But bottom line, as I put the pieces together, it's quite clear to me in the end of three months that we really have a very good platform. We have some of the best building blocks and some of the best platform to really be able to take off and grow on. So this is a high level thing on observation.
Yes.

Okay. On the, quick this thing. So I think if you look at the results for '09 for DBS and frankly I don't claim ownership for the results, but – and secondly, as objective as you or the analyst can on this sort of thing. I think frankly it's a strong set of results. A 9% growth on the top line in the economic environment of last year is actually very strong. It's very good and then, because, and like every other smart banker around the world when you have a tough economic time, the controllable you have is your expense base. So DBS did a good job controlling expenses.

The arrangement on the expenses, which gave 17% growth, and operating profit. 17% operating profit growth is pretty damn good, by any measure. Clearly, the bottom line, earnings are flat to '08 and that really reflects the credit cycle we are in. The credit environment and the credit cycle that we are in. I'll speak about that in a second, but just sticking to income growth, the income growth is pretty balanced, so despite the interest rate environment, I spoke a minute ago about the fact that DBS gets really badly hurt in down cycles in interest rate right.

Despite the interest rate environment, we will able to get a 4% growth on the net interest income line. That's very good. That speaks of some pretty efficient management on the asset books. And 24% growth in non-interest income to $2.15 billion, now that's again not in this and Sok Hui will speak to it, it's also fairly balanced, it not only includes good trading performance, which a lot of the houses dive and we have a good trading house, but included really robust performances in areas as diverse as the capital markets and investment banking, and a loan book and so on. So it is a good, diversified performance team.

Back to the credit cycle. So as a bank we've generally tried to be prudent. I think we've done a fairly good job of doing that. Our NPLs are obviously at a high, but as Sok Hui will point out, we tend to be conservative in our recognition of NPLs. And so we take things into non-performing before they necessarily need to be taken and before a lot of our, the global benchmarks are in terms of when you take them into non-performing.

And one of the good things we did in the last quarter frankly is that we still had a residual CDO portfolio. Not sub-prime, sub-prime we pretty much provided for before. But we had a fairly large $700 million of non sub-prime only business in the portfolio. We've pretty much been able to get rid of all of that. And so really from the exposure that we still have on our books, so the vulnerability, we've sort of – we manage to put that behind us. I think what I'm actually quite pleased about as I look back at what DBS did is this thing about standing by the customer.

Boon Hwee, I think a year ago and several of you reported it, came out and said DBS will stand by customers through this down cycle. And, we can look back with some satisfaction that we were really able to demonstrate doing that. In the consumer banking front, we not only stayed with customers, we were able to actually increase our loans dramatically, so we are out there lending. This is our strongest loan growth here ever for DBS. And that's actually saying something and 13% growth rates over the previous year.

We continue to stay Singapore's largest mortgage loan provider. And frankly we're doing that, we're also building up our deposit base, which is a good thing. But I think that was an important statement. And on the SME side as well we continued to build, I told you, our SME business is continuing to gain momentum. And in '09 I think that was demonstrated.

We were a leading lender in the government loan programs. More than half of the government loans that we approved were to new customers, so we weren't just stopping up loans to previous customers. And even in Hong Kong, we disbursed over 4 billion Hong Kong dollars and so we're rated the best SME partner in 2009. So we've been out there standing by our customers whether in the consumer segment, the SME segment. We're also able to do a lot of good things in the Capital Market side.

That was a capital market, as you know, came through quite nicely, certainly in the Asian space, both in fixed income and equities and we are quite proud of the fact that we were able to leverage our platform in Singapore to retain some fairly impressive leadership positions. Of all the rights issues done in Singapore last year we did 76%, while 75% of funds raised in Singapore. We are number one in the SGD bond market with more than 25% share. We were number one in the Singapore REIT market with 29% market share. So clearly, our range of our customer activities was very strong.

And finally, outside the region we were quite pleased with our progress in particularly two countries Taiwan and India. In Taiwan we integrated Bowa and we had our own internal projections for how long it would take and when we could make it profitable, while we became profitable in '09 and that was you know, a year ahead of what we thought we could do. So that was actually a great result.

And in India, I mean, as growth rates have been astronomical, we've been sort of growing at a CAGR of almost 100% for the last few years and '09 were no exception, but just a very strong performance. So with that I'm going to pass you over to Sok Hui who's going to take you through some more details of our financial performance and our numbers.

Thank you, Piyush. A very good afternoon to all of you. We delivered a strong set of results for 2009. Revenue were up 9% to 6.6 billion. Profits before allowances reached a record 4 billion in a fragile economic environment, up 17% from the previous quarter. The performance was underpinned by broad-based revenue and business volume growth as we stood by our customers. Net interest income was up 4% to a record 4.5 billion. Backed by our strong balance sheet, we grew our market share of Singapore Dollar loans for the second consecutive year from 18% at end of 2007 to just over 20% currently.

In Hong Kong, we have a loan market share of 5.6%, the highest in several years. Non-interest income was up 24% to 2.2 billion. Full year expenses were unchanged as we reined in expenses in the face of a challenging environment. The stronger operating performance was offset by higher allowances, which doubled to 1.5 billion from the previous year. We continue to adopt a prudent approach to recognizing NPLs and setting aside allowances. The increase in NPLs was largely due to borrowers outside of Asia, in particular the Middle East. Asset quality in our main markets in Asia has been improving since the second half of 2009. Net profit for 2009 was 2.1 billion, unchanged from the previous year.

Our fourth quarter earnings were 493 million, up 29% from a year ago. Like the earlier quarters of the year, we grew revenues faster than cost. Net interest income was stable as margins were resilient and momentum in mortgage lending was sustained. Non-interest income was 25% higher with a wide range of fee income activities benefiting from better capital market and economic conditions. Expenses rose 2% due to higher accruals for technology projects and higher seasonal advertising and promotional activities.

We took additional allowances this quarter in line with our prudent approach on asset quality. This quarter, the allowances were mainly for exposures outside of Asia. We also took the opportunity of better market conditions to divest some 650 million of our non-ADS CDO investments in the fourth quarter. Adequate allowances have been set aside which was more than sufficient to offset the loss on the sale of the portfolio. The remaining CDO/CLO portfolios are adequately provisioned and we have put the issue behind us. There was also a net tax write back of 47 million this quarter as we reached resolution on prior year's tax position. Compared to the previous quarter, net profit fell 12%, as revenues were stable for seasonal year-end expenses contributed to a 10% increase in costs.

Full year net interest income rose 4% to a new high of 4.5 billion. Asset growth was led by housing loans. Net interest margin was firm and funding cost was tightly managed to offset the impact of lower market interest rates. Fourth quarter net interest income was steady from the previous quarter at 1.1 billion. Loans grew 2% over the quarter bringing full year loan growth to 3%.

Loan growth for the quarter and the year was led by housing loans as we enjoyed strong disbursements in Singapore and Hong Kong. Overall, housing loans rose 7% for the quarter and 13% for the year. Business loans were little changed for the quarter and for the year, in line with the industry. For the full year, fee income rose 9% to 1.4 billion, leading the growth to investment banking and loan related fees. With capital markets recovering from dislocations in 2008, we benefited from activities including equity offerings, Singapore Dollar bonds and mid-market M&A advisory, for which we continue to lead in Singapore. This helped to offset declines in wealth management fee income. Other non-interest income rose 65% to 754 million driven by strong trading gains as a result of better trading opportunities.

For the fourth quarter, fee income was 358 million, little changed from the previous quarter. Investment banking fees was stronger, which offset declines in stock broking and other fee activities. Other non-interest income was also stable.

Full-year expenses: full-year expenses were unchanged at 2.6 billion, as we maintained expenses in a challenging environment. Fourth quarter expenses rose 10% from the previous quarter, driven by increased accrual for technology projects and higher seasonal advertising and promotional activities. These increases were partially offset by lower staff cost.

Hong Kong: Hong-Kong full-year earnings rose 19% in Singapore dollar terms to 464 million from lower cost and allowances. Revenue fell 3% due to weaker contributions from unit trust, insurance, and trade finance activities and lower gains from the sale of investments. Net interest income was stable and margins improved underpinned by higher customer loan volumes.

Expenses declined 17%, the previous year's expenses included significant non-recurring expenses. Allowances fell 10% as asset quality improved from the second quarter. NPL rate, which had peaked at 2.6% in the first quarter, improved progressively to 1.7% at end 2009 and changed from end 2008.

Hong Kong's fourth quarter performance reflected a continuation of recent operating trend. Net earnings of 128 million were significantly above a year ago as expenses and allowances declined. Revenues rose 2% from a year ago. Non-interest income was boosted by unit trust, insurance, stock broking, loan-related activities, and treasury product sales to corporate. Net interest income was boosted by loan growth, but offset by record low interest rates.

Expenses fell 25% from a year ago as there's been significant non-recurring expenses in the fourth quarter of 2008. Allowances fell two-thirds from a year ago as asset quality continued to improve. Specific allowances were below a year ago and a little changed from the previous quarter. The increase in allowances from the previous quarter was due to general allowances in line with loan growth.

Non-performing loans – non-performing assets rose 10% from the previous quarter to 4.2 billion, mainly due to exposure in the Middle East. 43% of assets classified as non-performing assets are still current in interests and principals. Our Group NPL now stands at 2.9%. NPL rates in most markets, including Singapore, Greater China, South and South East Asia improved during the quarter. The increase in NPL came largely from the rest of the world. Cumulative allowances remain healthy. Including collateral, allowances coverage amounted to more than 100% of non-performing assets.

We divested most of our non-ABS CDO investments during the quarter, reducing our total CDO investments to 195 million from 859 million in the previous quarter. The remaining 45 million of non-ABS CDOs will mature in 2010 and 2011. The 150 million ABS CDOs already have an allowance coverage exceeding 90%. With Tier 1 capital adequacy ratio of 13.1% and total CAR of 16.7%, our capital position remain strong and comfortably above regulatory requirement. We're in a healthy position to take advantage of economic upturn.

We're proposing final dividends of $0.14 per share. Based on yesterday's closing share price, DBS shares give investors an annualized dividend yield of 3.9%. The DBS Scrip Dividend Scheme, which was approved at the previous AGM will be applicable to the new – to the final dividend. New shares will be issued to shareholders who elect to receive the final dividend in script at a price, which is at a 5% discount to the average of the last dealt price for DBS shares on each of 20 May, 21 May and 24 May, 2010.

To sum up, our 2009 performance demonstrated the strength of our franchise as we focused on customers, costs and risk management. We achieved broad-based revenue growth underpinned by higher business volumes in consumer and corporate banking. We made efforts to rein in expenses given the fragile environment. We have been prudent in classifying non-performing assets and setting aside allowances.

Asset quality in our main Asian markets continue to improve. We divested a large part of our CLO investments, and already set aside ample allowances for the remaining one. Our balance sheet is strong. Our capital was reinforced with the rights issue earlier this year. Our deposit franchise also ensures us ample liquidity. With these we are well positioned as we work with customers to capture emerging opportunities in 2010 as the economic upturn continues.
I would now hand you back to Piyush to cover our strategic priorities.

Okay, thanks, Sok Hui. So, we have, in addition to spending a lot of time obviously trying to learn the business, we spent a lot of time equally as a management team thinking about what are the key things we need to do as a bank and where are we headed to. And we really defined, I guess, nine key priorities for ourselves; three each in the areas of geography, business build up and what we call enablers or perhaps more internal capabilities.

And before I dive into those, just as a preface, it's quite clear given where the world is and given where Asia is today that we are in the right part of the world and we are in the right place. Asia is where it's all happening. Asia is driving, increasing the growth. My economist colleague has this really neat chart, which he again showed us this morning, which suggests that 2010 is going to be a watershed year in many ways, because by our research for the first time Asia's contribution to incremental new demand in the world is going to outstrip the U.S. If you go back to 20 years ago, Asia's contribution to new demand used to be half of the U.S. It's been gradually increasing and we think in 2010 for the first time we would be 1.0 time – 02 times of the U.S., so, which is a big deal.

So, domestic consumption in Asia is indeed driving growth. And therefore, for us, as DBS, in terms of what kind of bank do we want to build and where do we want to play, that's a starting assumption. We really want to build an Asian franchise with an Asian footprint. I mentioned earlier we're privileged that over the last decade we've build good platform positions in what I call the three axis of growth in Asia. We have a position in the Greater China axis, we have a position in obviously in Singapore, and we have a position in the South Asia axis. And so we are well positioned.

Our aspiration is to continue to focus on this playing field. And in this playing field to build out a leading Pan-Asian regional bank, like the leading Asian bank. What that means therefore also that we are unlikely, we are unlikely pretty much will not be looking at expanding our businesses in domestic franchises in Europe and North America, frankly even in the Middle East. We have enough to do in our backyard and that's where we hope to focus – that's where we hope to build our future, certainly for the next five or ten years, foreseeable future.

So with that background, let me walk you through the nine priorities that we think will define what we intend to do in the next few years and frankly help us to achieving this leading Pan-Asian nation bank.

Number one priority – three geography priority – the number one priority for us is really we've got to entrench our leadership position in Singapore. We are privileged in some ways, because we have had the largest – we have been for a long time the largest bank in Singapore, we've got the best footprint in Singapore. But the truth also is we've just not capitalized enough on our position of strength. And so there are a few things that we think we need to do. One, I talked about earlier having an unbalanced balance sheet, right. And that's because we tend to be very deposit surplus.

One of the areas that we do need to focus on and concentrate is to build out our customer assets. And that is as much in the consumer space, whether it's home loans or unsecured lending, as in the SME space. So that is an area of priority we are going to continue to focus on doing that.

I spoke to you again earlier about the POSB franchise. It's a fantastic franchise and we have to be able to do a lot more with the franchise than we have hitherto. So seeing how we can build a more full service relationship with the POSB customer, how we can make it something more than just the savings bank, but into a broader relationship which includes financing, mortgage and so on, the right sort of investment choices, is something which will occupy us. It's something that we will focus on.

We do think that we have a unique opportunity to lead the payment space in the Singapore market, right. We already have, the reason that you see 10 people at every DBS ATM and zero at all the other ATMs is we already have a position as a payments provider in Singapore. We think we can leverage on that and really continue to build a leadership position in the space, and whether it's more modern payment, whether its debit cards, prepaid cards, mobile technology, but we will continue to focus and be the dominant provider in the payment space in Singapore.

And finally the fourth thing we've got to work very hard in improving our cross-sell across all our customer segments. And that's something which we can do frankly not only to make our relationships more meaningful, more sticky, but also to juice up the returns in our business. We tend to be loan-centric and loan-denominated. If we can start leveraging some of the capabilities we have in other areas and improve the cross-sell that will allow us to achieve therefore more customer's centricity but also improve the quality of our own earnings.
So, focus on Singapore, entrench our position in Singapore, make sure the leadership in Singapore counts, that's our number one geographic priority.

The second thing we need to do, and then a lot of people have talked about this; I call it re-energize Hong Kong. There's always a big question, right? The DBS paid too much for its acquisition in Hong Kong. And frankly, it's debatable. There are enough people who frankly in today's day and age, if you want to go and acquire a bank and do a deal, you could make a good case you didn't pay too much.

The more important issue however is what are we doing, and how are we being able to bring value from the integrated Hong Kong franchise that we have. And frankly that is an area of – which is going to be an area of focus for us in terms of what we can do to improve that. We have a good footprint. We have 50, 55 branches. So we can be a leading universal bank.

Our Hong Kong market shares today are in the 4, 5 – 3, 4, 5% range. Having a 5% plus market share in a banking system is not a bad market share at all. The bank I come from and most of the global banks are very happy to run with 4, 5% market shares because banking tends to be a very fragmented industry. So at a 5% market share you will very happily be in the number five to number ten position in the market, and you can build a sustainable business in that position; it can be a broad universal position.

But there are a couple of things we need to do. One we – I call it – we need to rebuild our management bench strength in Hong Kong. So what we've done in Hong Kong, it's been our source of talent, we've used it to build our China business, we've used it to build our Taiwan business; we've pulled functions out of Hong Kong and brought them to Singapore, in the process we've not devoted as much talent to the management bench to the Hong Kong proposition itself as perhaps we should. So that's something that will engage us, how do we re-energize, rebuild our management bench strength over there.

The second thing is – and we inherited and we got from, when we did the acquisition of Dao Heng, we inherited some really large and very interesting customer pools. So, on the consumer space we got circa 300 to 400,000 consumer customers, right. But we haven't done a very good job of segmenting those consumer pools, customer pools. We actually got a fantastic SME portfolio, but we haven't done a very good job of segmenting that SME portfolio, and driving and managing the distinction between the mid caps on the one side and the mom and pop shops on the other side. So, thinking through and developing a far better refined segmented strategy for our Hong Kong businesses will be a priority.
We believe that if we do that we can manage our presence in those segments better. And we believe we can improve the profitability of the business that we do by doing that segmentation.

The third thing, obviously in Hong Kong, we need to invest a little bit in rebuilding our brand, and all of you know, so we've stubbed our toes a couple of times in Hong Kong, both the safe deposit incident some years ago, and our investment sales in the last couple of years. So we will do that. We will invest in making sure that we invest in rebuilding our brand, so we are relevant, we're resonant and use a more segmented strategy to rebuild our Hong Kong position.

The third thing, we need to do, is I call it rebalance the geographic mix of our business. And that's really got a couple of elements to it. One is, as a team we've thought about this, if we really think Asia is the future, and Asia is going to propel our growth as a pan-regional, as an Asian bank, then our current mix of earnings, the current mix of our businesses, will probably have to be balanced somewhat over a period of time.

And frankly, as best as we can see together, what we really need to get to is this 40-30-30 kind of mix, maybe 40% of our business will be Singapore, it will be our anchor market, it will be our home market, and we really need to be big there. But we would like to be able to get maybe equal business presence in Greater China on the one side and what we call South and South East Asia on the other side, and so a more balanced mix of businesses.

From an organic standpoint, I mentioned, we really have good ability to build out a broader consumer proposition in Taiwan and Indonesia. In Taiwan, we have 40 plus branches and in Indonesia we have 40 branches and rapidly increasing. In both of these markets, we think in addition to doing corporate and SME kind of banking, we can – and affluent banking, we can actually go down to the next consumer segment, which is the upper middle class if you will. So and we think we will do that. In China and India it's a little more tricky because of the limitations on distribution. So our focus is likely to be in the corporate space, top-end corporate space, and in affluent consumer banking, right. Top-end corporate and frankly we can do SME banking in these countries and then affluent consumer banking. So that's the thinking we have around the rebalanced geographic mix of our businesses, so, three geographic priorities.

Outside of that, we've looked at our business and we really figure that while in most of our markets we have the capacity and will be a broad universal player, there are a couple of businesses, which are really important for us to build out, which we would like to be the go to bank in the region, right.

So we want to make sure that in these businesses we are known for excellence. The first of these is we want to build out a leading SME franchise, SME business across the multiple markets we're in, anchored around trade finance, right. This obviously speaks to the opportunity in Asia. And everybody knows both inter-Asia trade and intra-Asia trade is expanding. Asia's always been for the last twenty years the heart of the global supply chains, the global hubs, but interestingly Asia is now beginning to consume more of its own production as well.

So the spaghetti mesh of integrations across the countries in Asia is only going to increase exponentially. We believe that the opportunity to build the best-in-class bank in the space is still out there. And that's what we want; we want to run it with a reasonable business model. We want to develop best-in-class state finance capabilities. We have some very good competencies. We're one of the few banks which has warehouse financing capability. We have factoring capability, we have traditional trade finance, the LCs and bills capability. We have commodity risk-taking capability. We have exposure management capability in currency, rate, and some extent commodities.
